organization.fullName: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

identificationModule.briefTitle: Improving Ambulation Post Stroke With Robotic Training
identificationModule.officialTitle: Improving Ambulation Post Stroke With Robotic Training

responsibleParty.investigatorAffiliation: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

leadSponsor.name: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this research study is to look at a new rehabilitation technique for individuals who have suffered a stroke and have difficulties walking. This study is designed to compare robot-assisted (Lokomat) rehabilitation therapy with standard physical therapy in order to improve walking post-stroke. This research project will be conducted as a pilot randomized controlled trial that compares the effectiveness of Lokomat versus conventional physical therapy in improving the ambulation and gait of chronic stroke patients. The project will provide important pilot data that could indicate whether or not the effectiveness of Lokomat training is superior to that of standard physical therapy and if a definitive and larger clinical trial is warranted.

armGroups.label: Lokomat Intervention
armGroups.description: Lokomat gait training (five days a week for eight weeks for a total of 40 sessions).

armGroups.label: Standard of Care
armGroups.description: Conventional physical therapy focusing on gait training for five days a week for eight weeks for a total of 40 sessions.

primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 1 Week Post-Intervention (study mean of 5.05 days since last therapy session), 3-Month Post-Intervention

secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, 1-Week Post-Intervention (study mean of 5.05 days since last therapy session), 3-Month Post-Intervention

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Subjects with ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke confirmed by cerebral computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan
* Age\>18
* At least 3 months post stroke at time of enrollment into study
* Ability to walk at least 10 feet with maximum 1 person assist, but not to walk in the community independently
* Residual paresis in the lower extremity as defined by the National Institute of Health Stroke Scale lower extremity motor score 2-4
* Ability to perform Lokomat ambulation training with assistance of 1 therapist
* Ability to follow a three-step command
* Physician approval for patient participation
* Ability to give informed consent
* Completed their rehabilitation services, i.e., receiving no concurrent physical, occupational, or speech therapies

Exclusion Criteria:

* Serious cardiac condition
* Uncontrolled blood pressure, defined as \> 200 or diastolic \> 100 at rest
* Hx of serious chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or oxygen dependence
* Sever weight bearing pain
* Lower extremity amputation
* Claudication while walking
* Life expectancy \< 1 year
* History of deep vein thrombosis/pulmonary embolism (DVT/PE) within 6 months
* Severe orthopedic problem
* Any medical or psychiatric condition that the investigators believe would make the patient unable to participate in this study

overallOfficials.name: Elizabeth Noser, MD
overallOfficials.affiliation: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

outcomeMeasures.title: 10-meter Walking Test (10mWT)
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Analysis was determined per protocol (i.e.between-group variation)
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline, 1 Week Post-Intervention (study mean of 5.05 days since last therapy session), 3-Month Post-Intervention

groups.description: Baseline, 1-Week Post-Intervention (study mean of 5.05 days since last therapy session), 3-Month Post-Intervention assessment values measured by a blinded assessor.

groups.description: Baseline, 1-Week Post-Intervention (study mean of 5.05 days since last therapy session), 3-Month Post-Intervention assessment values measured by a blinded assessor.

outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline, 1-Week Post-Intervention (study mean of 5.05 days since last therapy session), 3-Month Post-Intervention

seriousEvents.notes: Skin breakdown as a result of therapy; adverse event deemed "definitely related" to protocol.
Sudden drop in blood pressure at subject's home leading to brief hospitalization; adverse event deemed "unrelated" to protocol.
Sudden chest pain prior to therapy leading to ER visit and brief hospitalization; adverse event deemed "unrelated" to protocol.
Subject with a second stroke during the post-treatment phase of study participation; adverse event deemed "unrelated" to protocol.

limitationsAndCaveats.description: Limitations include: small sample (n=21 enrolled, n=20 completed) and significant (p=0.025) difference between groups in time since stroke (Lokomat group, time since stroke mean=1353.60 days; Conventional group, time since stroke mean=525.00 days).
